description: Sander Vanocur interviews David F. Powers, a friend and political aide of John F. Kennedy, at the 1964 Democratic National Convention in Atlantic City, New Jersey. Vanocur conducted a series of interviews with Powers in 1964 for the book, "Johnny We Hardly Knew Ye." Vanocur was originally involved in this project, along with David Powers, Kenneth O'Donnell and Lawrence O'Brien. After a period of time, however, the book project was stopped. Later, Powers and O'Donnell decided to begin the project again, this time with the help of Joe McCarthy; on this second start Vanocur and O'Brien were not directly involved although Vanocur gave the interviews to Powers and O'Donnell. The interviews between Vanocur and Powers, however, proved to be the backbone of material for much of the book. This program begins with Vanocur describing taped footage of Jacqueline Kennedy’s appearances during the day which include her arrival at the airport and her remarks at a reception for the delegates. Powers then discusses the legacy and life of John F. Kennedy with Vanocur. In 1946, John F. Kennedy asked Powers to join his congressional campaign. Powers agreed and continued to work with John F. Kennedy on all of his subsequent campaigns, including the 1960 campaign for President. After Kennedy was elected, Powers served as Special Assistant to the President from 1961 to 1963. In 1964, he became the first curator of the John F. Kennedy Library, a position he held until 1994. Vanocur served as White House correspondent and national political correspondent for NBC News in the 1960s and early 1970s. He was one of the questioners at the first Kennedy-Nixon debate in 1960 and was also chosen as one of the questioners in the 1992 presidential debate.
title: Sander Vanocur interviews David Powers

description: May Sing, an annual competition among Northwestern University units, was part of Northwestern University's May Week program. Chip Thomson and Theta XI's performance of "High Noon" won first place for men's large group. Jennifer Haefele and Alpha Delta Pi's performance of "Johnny, I Hardley Know Ye" won first place for women's large group. Jean Morse and Alpha Phi's performance of "O Baby Mine" won first place for women's small group. George Middlekauf and Kappa Sigma's performance of "Lida Rose" won first place for men's small group. Buzz Stulac and Theta Chi's performance of "Eine Kleine Machtmusik, 4th movement" won second place men's large group. Ronald Swarsen and Thete Delta Chi's performance of "More" won third place men's large group.

description: Recounts, through the use of still photographs, the history of black students at Northwestern University's Evanston campus in the 1960s.
title: One generation ago-- : a scrapbook : an observance of an era, Norris University Center, May 18, 1991
physical_description_material: 1 videocassette (VHS) (29 min.) : sound, color with black and white sequences

notes.note: written, produced and directed by Cherilyn Wright and Barbara Perkins.

description: Aircheck before Northwestern University Student Symposium 1969. Part 1 features commentary and analysis by Claude Brown, James Herndon, and Thomas Ayers in a panel discussion on social change. Part 2 - An interview by Bill Smith with Will Ris, the co-chair of Northwestern University Student Symposium 1969. Panelists in the upcoming Symposium are introduced, including former Illinois Governor, Otto Kerner Jr. A synopsis of the week's programs and schedule is also provided. Part 3 - WNUR's Science Journal program
title: Northwestern University Student Symposium 1969 Aircheck

description: May Sing, an annual competition among Northwestern University units, was part of Northwestern University's May Week program. Bob Avery and Sally Lubek were co-chairman. Side 1 - Masters of Ceremony were Wes Anson and Stu Shakman. Side 2 - Masters of Ceremony were Tom Dickson and Barry Shanoff.

description: WNUR programming. Part 1 is a news report. Part 2 features part of the Public Affairs program. The OLD (Organisms for a Longer Day) are interviewed. Another segment takes places at the Africa House of Northwestern during the Africa Presence Week.
title: WNUR Audio Tapes, News and Public Affairs Reports
